How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>Input: The marching band has 110 members.  There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Christian is twice as old as Brian. In eight more years, Brian will be 40 years old. How old will Christian be in eight years?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>Input: It rained twice as much on Tuesday as Monday.  On Monday it rained 3 inches more than Sunday.  It rained 4 inches on Sunday.  How much total rainfall was there over the 3 days?<n>Answer: 25<n><n>Input: Anne drops a mirror and breaks it into 60 pieces. She sweeps up half of them, then her cat steals 3 pieces and her boyfriend picks up 1/3 of the remaining pieces. How many pieces does her boyfriend pick up?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Francis' family has 2 ukuleles, 4 guitars, and a certain number of violins. Each ukulele has 4 strings. Each guitar has 6 strings. Each violin has 4 strings. If the total number of strings among the ukuleles, guitars, and violins is 40 strings, how many violins does Francis' family have?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>Input: On each of 7 Mondays, it rained 1.5 centimeters. On each of 9 Tuesdays it rained 2.5 centimeters. How many more centimeters did it rain on Tuesdays than Mondays?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: The Reptile House at the zoo has 5 fewer animals than 3 times the number of animals housed in the Rain Forest exhibit. If the Reptile House has 16 animals, how many are in the Rain Forest exhibit?<n>Answer: 7<n><n>### Input:Where is a fox likely to be caught? How much soda does the 3.5 liter contain?   - Dr. Lindenberg has over 4,400 patients.  If she has over 500 fewer patients than double her second most popular specialty, what is Dr. Lindenberg's second most popular specialty?   - The difference between a negative number and a positive number, the square root of a negative number, the square root or a positive number, and an even number are integers. Which is true?   - Mrs. Anderson has five more marbles than three times the number she has. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon. Choices:  A: weak B: fragile C: forceless D: regular E: flimsy<n><n>### Response:		A) <n><n>### Demostration<n>```perl -e'my @fragile = ( 1, 2, 3 ); my $forceless = $fragile[1] * @($fragile[0..1]); say $forceless'<n>```<n><n>### InputGlass is so strong that if you try to break it it doesn't break.  What type of glass is this? Choices:A) Clear B) Fragile C) Thick D) Regular E) Strong<n><n>### Response<n>```bash<n>set -- 'A'<n>echo $1 | cut -f2<n>```<n><n>## Below is an instruction that asks the user to supply input (in a specified format for the task), perform computation or actions on the specified data.<n><n>### Input<n>```bash<n>echo -e "please enter a word"<n>read -r user<n>```<n><n>## Demonstration<n>```bash<n>echo "please enter a number"<n>read -r number<n>```<n>### Input<n>Input: Please choose how many 0's you want to be in the number.Choices: A) 0 B) 5 C) 7 <n><n>### Response1<n>```bash<n>read -p "how many 0's do you want\!? " num<n>echo ${num:0:1}<n>echo ${num}<n>echo ${num:1}<n>```<n><n>```bash<n>$ echo $RANDOM<n>1337<n>0<n>```<n><n>Output: 01337<n><n>### Response2<n>```bash<n><n>```<n>### Demomstration<n>```bash <n>read -rc 'Please enter a string to check for palindromes. Choices: A) abcdefghiJKMNOPqrsTUV  B) abracadabra<n>c<n><n>```<n><n><n>### Response 3<n>```python<n><n><n><n>```<n># print (name.lower())<n>read -p "Please type your name!" name<n>echo $name | tr [:upper:] [:lower:]<n># print (name[-1])<n>read -r name[0:-1]<n>echo $name<n># print (name[::]<n>read -p "please input string" string<n>echo $string

If the Reptile House has 16 animals, how many are in the Rain Forest exhibit?<n>Answer: 7<n><n>### Input:What is an area with no grass where I can get things to sell at a roadside stand? Choices:  A: surface of earth B: rest area C: supermarket D: state park E: garden<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Choices:  B: rest area, C: supermarket.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>We will show that each choice leads to a different value for the variables. We are asked the choices for items at a roadside stand, so it makes sense to make choices for the items.<n><n>The rest area does not have things to sell. We would have to buy them.  Thus, A is excluded from further consideration.<n><n>A supermarket is not the same as a roadside stand, since a roadside stand does not have regular business hours or a regular customer base.  If we want to sell things, we will not be in a supermarket.  Supermarkets are closed overnight.  We want to have our stand open overnight to avoid being robbed.  Choice C is excluded from further considerations.<n><n>A state park offers camping sites and hiking trails.  We do not mind about camping sites, so we can exclude park A, and we don't want any hiking trails, so park D is excluded.<n><n>That leaves our choices A, B, C, D.<n><n>Now we will explore our choices.<n><n>What would a rest area A contain?  We would expect to be able to rest there, perhaps have a snack or drink at a cashier station or a vending machine, perhaps get fuel to run the roadside stand, etc.  We would not expect to be able to sell things there.  Thus, there can be no items for sale at a rest area.  A is excluded.<n> <n>What would a supermarket C contain?  We would be able to sell things, and we would be able to get things to sell there.  However, the cost of electricity, water and a storefront is too much for us to operate with that income.  We need to get things to sell ourselves, and we don' have that kind of income.  No income, no business.  C is excluded.<n>  <n>What would park A state park contain?  We are told "what is an area with no [things to sell]", so we need to determine what an area with that name would contain.  We can say that that area has grass and trees.  We cannot expect there to be any people there, so we can expect the rest of the things to be not required

How many pieces does her boyfriend pick up?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Francis' family has 2 ukuleles, 4 guitars, and a certain number of violins. Each ukulele has 4 strings. Each guitar has 6 strings. Each violin has 4 strings. If the total number of strings among the ukuleles, guitars, and violins is 40 strings, how many violins does Francis' family have?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>Input: On each of 7 Mondays, it rained 1.5 centimeters. On each of 9 Tuesdays it rained 2.5 centimeters. How many more centimeters did it rain on Tuesdays than Mondays?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: The Reptile House at the zoo has 5 fewer animals than 3 times the number of animals housed in the Rain Forest exhibit. If the Reptile House has 16 animals, how many are in the Rain Forest exhibit?<n>Answer: 7<n><n>### Input:What has a master of their craft done about that craft? Choices:  A: drill B: committed murder most vile C: bargemaster D: learn E: understand<n><n>### Response:		Input:<n>Choice: E<n><n>### Justification:<n>The answer choice which correctly summarizes the question is letter E.  A drill has a master who has "mastered" the drilling aspect of their craft, therefore, their work makes the craft "master," as in "good."  The word "commit" in B is not indicative of mastery, but of criminal liability (to "commit murder" suggests something criminal, as in a violent crime).  Thus "learn" and "understand" would not work to describe mastery (that would imply a skill level) and neither C nor D are appropriate either.<n><n>

He washed 20 dishes the first day, then 30 dishes the second day, then 40 dishes on the third day. By the time he had washed a total of 120 dishes, how many dishes had he washed in the first three days combined?<n><n>### Answer: The answer is D<n><n>### Why?<n>The number of dishes in the 1 st 2 nd and 3 rd days combined becomes d+2d+3=5d<n><n>d+2d+3-120 = 5d<n>2d-236 = 5d<n>d=30<n><n>### Input  : The question reads Every day, he washes one-third as many  dishes as the number he washed the previous  day.  He  washes 20 dishes on the 1st   day, then 31  dishes  the 2nd  day,  and  then 40  dishes on  the 3rd  day.  By the time he  washes a total of 171 dishes, how many  dishes  did  he  wash  in  the  first  three  days?<n><n>### Response  :  The answer is E.<n><n>### Answer  :  523  - 171 = 352 dishes<n><n>### Why   :  2 + 3 + 4 = 9 - we can't add to one-third as the sum will be 523<n><n>### Input   : Every year, he eats one-third as many turkeys as he  eats  the  previous  year. If the Reptile House has 16 animals, how many are in the Rain Forest exhibit?<n>Answer: 7<n><n>### Input:How is someone who loves their TV likely to feel about their remote? Choices:  A: attached B: nostalgic C: companionable D: likely E: close<n><n>### Response:		The answer is A.  A remote control and television may be very old, used, and worn. But you don't want to throw away the remote control because of all those memories associated with it. The remote was something used when spending time with friends and family. Something that is familiar, as the remote is a familiar and reliable tool.  While you may lose connections and friendships with those people, the remote control may still be there and available. The relationship that was lost can not be replaced.<n><n>### Input How did the penguin feel about the walrus when they got married? Choices: 1. Annoyance 2. Agony 3. Anxiety 4. Ambitious 5. Aspect<n><n>### Response A number like 5 can never feel like 42. A number can always feel like a number. A large or small number may feel good or bad. But how can an emotion itself be a number? A penguin can only feel emotions like happiness, anger, sadness, or joy. Penguins are not human. For them to have emotions and have a feeling towards anything, they would need to be able to have human emotions. That would require a form of intelligence, of some kind or another. The human brain is vast compared to that of a penguin. There is not much that people know about a penguin's brain. There is not even enough evidence and observation to be able to determine if such an emotional feeling would be possible in a penguin. As a conclusion, I can say that a penguin, while they probably have emotions, will not be able to understand or fully describe this emotion to a human. Therefore, a penguin cannot feel agony or annoyance, either those emotions do not exist in penguins or the penguin has a completely different sense of what it means to feel either of those emotions.<n><n>### 4.Which of the following colors is less visible than the others? Choose one answer. A: blue  B: green  C: red  D: yellow<n><n>### Response Blue has the lowest visibility out of all the colors present in the question.  The more visible a color is in the sunlight, the more it will be impacted by the rays of the sun. This is why blue is never the color you see

You look up at the sky and it is endless. Choice C is stellar because you feel "mighty" from the immense magnitude of the sky.  <n><n>### Solution_Expectations:Solutions can be any of the choices, so long as "feeling mighty" can be logically inferred from the magnitude of the sky. Solutions cannot be "feeling sad."<n>

If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>Input: The marching band has 110 members.  There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Christian is twice as old as Brian. In eight more years, Brian will be 40 years old. How old will Christian be in eight years?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>Input: It rained twice as much on Tuesday as Monday.  On Monday it rained 3 inches more than Sunday.  It rained 4 inches on Sunday.  How much total rainfall was there over the 3 days?<n>Answer: 25<n><n>Input: Anne drops a mirror and breaks it into 60 pieces. She sweeps up half of them, then her cat steals 3 pieces and her boyfriend picks up 1/3 of the remaining pieces. How many pieces does her boyfriend pick up?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Francis' family has 2 ukuleles, 4 guitars, and a certain number of violins. Each ukulele has 4 strings. Each guitar has 6 strings. Each violin has 4 strings. If the total number of strings among the ukuleles, guitars, and violins is 40 strings, how many violins does Francis' family have?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>Input: On each of 7 Mondays, it rained 1.5 centimeters. On each of 9 Tuesdays it rained 2.5 centimeters. How many more centimeters did it rain on Tuesdays than Mondays?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: The Reptile House at the zoo has 5 fewer animals than 3 times the number of animals housed in the Rain Forest exhibit. If the Reptile House has 16 animals, how many are in the Rain Forest exhibit?<n>Answer: 7<n><n>### Input:John joined the army because he wanted to see the world.  When the fighting started, he only saw what sort of things? Choices:  A: fort B: orphans C: battlefield D: other countries E: war<n><n>### Response:		<n>John joined the army because **he wanted to see the world**. ***<n><n>The fighting started, he only ***saw fighting***<n><n>### Inputï¼šAnnie went to a hotel near a beach.  Her room had 43 windows.  She took 3 times as many pillows as towels.  If there were 49 other people in the hotel besides her, how many other people took different amounts of towels and pillows?<n><n>### Response<n><n>There were 49 other peoples in the hotel besides her. ***<n>***<n>There were 43 windows. **<n><n>Annie took ***three times as many pillows***.<n><n>### Input<n><n>Annie and her two brothers are playing a game. There are ten squares on the game board. Annie took five pieces of licorice and placed them on two squares, one in the northeast and one in the southwest, leaving two squares between them.  Her brother took two pieces of licorice, placed them on two squares of the game board, leaving two squares between. Their grandmother took three pieces of licorice from the table and put them in one square. How many pieces of licorice are left?<n><n>### Solution<n><n>**There are seven licorice pieces left**<n><n>The solution: Three pieces of licorice were left.

If the July and June pound cake consumption was 389 pounds and 76 pounds respectively, how much is eaten in July?<n><n>### Response<n>142<n><n>### Input1:Which of the following is greater than 25? A: 26 B: 32 C: 25 D: All answers are greater than 25<n><n>### Response1:  D greater of all<n><n>### Input2:Find the largest number among these three? A. 37 B. 2 C: 28 D. 29<n><n>### Response2:  C B<n><n>### Input3:If a person has more money than you does, are they richer? A: yes B:no C: I don't know D: I don't think so<n><n>### Response3:  B not<n><n>### Input4:Which is most like the number 25? A. 12 B. 18 C.4<n><n>### Response4:  C least<n><n>### Input5:Which of the numbers below is the highest out of these numbers? A. 64 B. 112 C. 150 D. 163<n><n>### Response5: D the sum is the highest<n><n>### Input6: Which is correct? A. 3 / 10 = 0.3 B. 3 / 7 = 0.2<n><n>### Response6:  a <n><n>### Input7: How much milk does a cow give birth to? A. the same number as that of what it ate B. 6 times as much as that of what it eats C. 4 times what it ate D. All of above are correct<n><n>### Response7:  b<n><n>### Input8: What is the largest number of the trio? A. 15 B. 25 C. 16 D. 17<n><n>### Response8: B<n><n>This week, we continue with the basic problem-solving strategies. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Five less than three times the number of Doberman puppies plus the difference between the number of Doberman puppies and the number of Schnauzers is equal to 90. If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>Input: The marching band has 110 members.  There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Christian is twice as old as Brian. In eight more years, Brian will be 40 years old. How old will Christian be in eight years?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>Input: It rained twice as much on Tuesday as Monday.  On Monday it rained 3 inches more than Sunday.  It rained 4 inches on Sunday.  How much total rainfall was there over the 3 days?<n>Answer: 25<n><n>Input: Anne drops a mirror and breaks it into 60 pieces. She sweeps up half of them, then her cat steals 3 pieces and her boyfriend picks up 1/3 of the remaining pieces. How many pieces does her boyfriend pick up?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Francis' family has 2 ukuleles, 4 guitars, and a certain number of violins. Each ukulele has 4 strings. Each guitar has 6 strings. Each violin has 4 strings. If the total number of strings among the ukuleles, guitars, and violins is 40 strings, how many violins does Francis' family have?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>Input: On each of 7 Mondays, it rained 1.5 centimeters. On each of 9 Tuesdays it rained 2.5 centimeters. How many more centimeters did it rain on Tuesdays than Mondays?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: The Reptile House at the zoo has 5 fewer animals than 3 times the number of animals housed in the Rain Forest exhibit. If the Reptile House has 16 animals, how many are in the Rain Forest exhibit?<n>Answer: 7<n><n>### Input:Where is a note likely to indicate a melody? Choices: A: 4.8 pounds B: 8.2 pounds C: 17.7 pounds D: 12.6 pounds<n><n>### Response If you put a 3 pound weight on the center of the toy snake, the weight will be shared to 4.8 pounds on each end of the toy snae. <n><n>### Input Four times a number plus the number is a prime number. To Washington<n><n>### Response C. the mountains<n><n>### You have $18 to spend on groceries. Your father is not very rich, and you want to take him to a good restaurant on Father's Day. If the total number of strings among the ukuleles, guitars, and violins is 40 strings, how many violins does Francis' family have?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>Input: On each of 7 Mondays, it rained 1.5 centimeters. On each of 9 Tuesdays it rained 2.5 centimeters. How many more centimeters did it rain on Tuesdays than Mondays?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: The Reptile House at the zoo has 5 fewer animals than 3 times the number of animals housed in the Rain Forest exhibit. If the Reptile House has 16 animals, how many are in the Rain Forest exhibit?<n>Answer: 7<n><n>### Input:The child pounded his mitt in excitement while enjoying his first game in the bleachers where? Choices:  A: football stadium B: laboratory C: baseball stadium D: pharmacy E: soccer game<n><n>### Response:		The answer choices are A,F,G,H,J.<n><n>### Input : A large group of children played a game after recess. How old will Christian be in eight years?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>Input: It rained twice as much on Tuesday as Monday.  On Monday it rained 3 inches more than Sunday.  It rained 4 inches on Sunday.  How much total rainfall was there over the 3 days?<n>Answer: 25<n><n>Input: Anne drops a mirror and breaks it into 60 pieces. She sweeps up half of them, then her cat steals 3 pieces and her boyfriend picks up 1/3 of the remaining pieces. How many pieces does her boyfriend pick up?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Francis' family has 2 ukuleles, 4 guitars, and a certain number of violins. Each ukulele has 4 strings. Each guitar has 6 strings. Each violin has 4 strings. If the total number of strings among the ukuleles, guitars, and violins is 40 strings, how many violins does Francis' family have?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>Input: On each of 7 Mondays, it rained 1.5 centimeters. On each of 9 Tuesdays it rained 2.5 centimeters. How many more centimeters did it rain on Tuesdays than Mondays?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: The Reptile House at the zoo has 5 fewer animals than 3 times the number of animals housed in the Rain Forest exhibit. If the Reptile House has 16 animals, how many are in the Rain Forest exhibit?<n>Answer: 7<n><n>### Input:The person knew the police were after him, so what did he do? Choices:  A: the sun B: catch cold C: prepare to go D: feel humiliated E: hunt for food<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer:<n>[choose A]<n><n>### Input The police decided to follow the person to his home. Where did they see him? Choices: A: outside in a shopping center B: inside the museum C: in front of a restaurant D: in a hotel swimming pool E: in a public garden by the river<n><n>### Response<n>Answer:<n>[select E]<n><n>### In this case, what was the most likely to happen to the police if they followed the person to his home? Choices:  I: the person caught the police because they broke the law.  II: the person called the police about one of the policeman. I: 3.1.4.1.  II: 4.1.3.1. If one person is more likely to happen, write I. If two persons are more likely to happen, I is acceptable.<n><n>### Response[select 2]<n><n>### <n>

If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>Input: The marching band has 110 members.  There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Christian is twice as old as Brian. In eight more years, Brian will be 40 years old. How old will Christian be in eight years?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>Input: It rained twice as much on Tuesday as Monday.  On Monday it rained 3 inches more than Sunday.  It rained 4 inches on Sunday.  How much total rainfall was there over the 3 days?<n>Answer: 25<n><n>Input: Anne drops a mirror and breaks it into 60 pieces. She sweeps up half of them, then her cat steals 3 pieces and her boyfriend picks up 1/3 of the remaining pieces. How many pieces does her boyfriend pick up?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Francis' family has 2 ukuleles, 4 guitars, and a certain number of violins. Each ukulele has 4 strings. Each guitar has 6 strings. Each violin has 4 strings. If the total number of strings among the ukuleles, guitars, and violins is 40 strings, how many violins does Francis' family have?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>Input: On each of 7 Mondays, it rained 1.5 centimeters. On each of 9 Tuesdays it rained 2.5 centimeters. How many more centimeters did it rain on Tuesdays than Mondays?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: The Reptile House at the zoo has 5 fewer animals than 3 times the number of animals housed in the Rain Forest exhibit. If the Reptile House has 16 animals, how many are in the Rain Forest exhibit?<n>Answer: 7<n><n>### Input:Someone who is awake is likely to know what's going on because they are this? Choices:  <n>  A: supermarket  <n>  B: home  <n>  C: closet  <n>  D: mart  <n>  E: hardware store <n><n>Answer: C<n><n>### Instuctions<n><n>### Demo<n><n>If the number of students enrolled in Algebra I (AI) at a middle school in 2011 increased twice as fast as the number of AI students that same year, what was the rate of increase?  If the number of AI courses increased 10% to 50, what was the number of courses in the first year?<n><n>### Inte<n><n>One year, the number enrolled in AI is 640, the rate in the second year was 24.8 % and the number of students enrolling in AI was 780. What was the ratio of students in the first year to the second year?<n><n>## Instruction<n><n>The first sentence is a definition. Choose the most appropriate definition to the word 'perpendicular'.<n><n>## Instructions<n><n>The first sentence defines the number and the second sentence defines 'divisible'. Choose the most appropriate word to complete the sentence.<n><n>## Instruc<n><n>Complete the definition of 'decreased'.<n><n>## Instruct<n><n>Complete the list using the alphabet.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Five less than three times the number of Doberman puppies plus the difference between the number of Doberman puppies and the number of Schnauzers is equal to 90. If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>Input: The marching band has 110 members.  There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Christian is twice as old as Brian. In eight more years, Brian will be 40 years old. How old will Christian be in eight years?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>Input: It rained twice as much on Tuesday as Monday.  On Monday it rained 3 inches more than Sunday.  It rained 4 inches on Sunday.  How much total rainfall was there over the 3 days?<n>Answer: 25<n><n>Input: Anne drops a mirror and breaks it into 60 pieces. She sweeps up half of them, then her cat steals 3 pieces and her boyfriend picks up 1/3 of the remaining pieces. How many pieces does her boyfriend pick up?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Francis' family has 2 ukuleles, 4 guitars, and a certain number of violins. Each ukulele has 4 strings. Each guitar has 6 strings. Each violin has 4 strings. If the total number of strings among the ukuleles, guitars, and violins is 40 strings, how many violins does Francis' family have?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>Input: On each of 7 Mondays, it rained 1.5 centimeters. On each of 9 Tuesdays it rained 2.5 centimeters. How many more centimeters did it rain on Tuesdays than Mondays?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: The Reptile House at the zoo has 5 fewer animals than 3 times the number of animals housed in the Rain Forest exhibit. If the Reptile House has 16 animals, how many are in the Rain Forest exhibit?<n>Answer: 7<n><n>### Input:How does a flea locomote? Choices:  A: attack B: suck blood C: stay D: lay eggs E: jump<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Input<n>A: 3 + 5 = 7 x 2 + 3 = 11 + 5 = 16 - 2 = 14<n><n>### Response<n>A<n><n>### Instructions: <n><n>### Input - Answer choices:<n><n>### Demographics:<n>1. 90% of women 20-35 years old<n>2. 25% of men 30-35 years of age<n>3. 10% of women 31-34 years old<n>4. 15% of men 26-29 years old<n>5. 7% of women 26-28 years old<n>6. 32% of women 25 years old<n><n>### Questions:<n><n>### Question 1:<n>If half of the women who participated in a nationwide survey were under 41, half of these were under 31, and two-thirds were under 25, how many were at least 11 years old?<n><n>1. 80% of the women who participated were 16<n>2. 16% of the women who particiated were 5<n>3. 14% of the women who participation were 3<n>4. 60% of those who participated were 35<n>5. 18% of those who participated are 31<n><n>### Question2:<n><n>If 7% were 40 and 9% were over 65, and 25% were under 30, and 20% were over 35, what percent were at least 55?<n><n>1.  5% were at least 50<n>2.  43% were at least 35<n>3.  20% were over at least 35 years old<n>4.  40% were at least 40 years old<n>5.  39% were at least 65 years old<n><n>```<n><n>### Demographic survey<n><n>### How many women were in the survey?<n>1. 30,000<n>2. 277,000<n>3. 207,200<n>4. 196,450<n>

If the Reptile House has 16 animals, how many are in the Rain Forest exhibit?<n>Answer: 7<n><n>### Input:What happens when humans are exposed to noises? Choices:  A: pet the dog B: hear sounds C: have sex D: reproduce E: drive cars<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Input (Instruction): If you add the first two integers on any list and then add the last two integers on the list, you will always get the sum of all the numbers. Write the statement below so any number can be input and output is printed.<n><n>### Example: 1 2 3 4 5 6<n>12<n>5 4 3 2 1<n>11<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>Input: 1 2<n>Output: 3<n><n>Input: 5 4<n>Output: 9<n><n>### Analysis:<n><n>The purpose of the program is to be a calculator that takes two numbers and sums them and then uses that same method to find the sum of multiple series of that same method. It took a few times to understand the algorithm because the number list is 2-diminstional.<n><n>### Algorithm:<n>Start at the beginning of the list and subtract the first number in the list from the second until you reach the last number in the list. That is the first sum of the list.<n>Then take the beginning of every other number in the list and subtract the sum until you reach the last. This will give you a second total with the same method that was used before.<n>If the first total was greater than the second total then it would mean that the first number on the list was also the greatest number.<n><n>### Input(Algorithm) : The number of numbers in a given list will take precedence and will define the number of the loop. The algorithm can then repeat or stop once the end of the list is reached and the number of numbers left is 1.<n><n>### Output (Algorithm):<n>The program should always output the sum of both series of numbers.

If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>Input: The marching band has 110 members.  There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Christian is twice as old as Brian. In eight more years, Brian will be 40 years old. How old will Christian be in eight years?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>Input: It rained twice as much on Tuesday as Monday.  On Monday it rained 3 inches more than Sunday.  It rained 4 inches on Sunday.  How much total rainfall was there over the 3 days?<n>Answer: 25<n><n>Input: Anne drops a mirror and breaks it into 60 pieces. She sweeps up half of them, then her cat steals 3 pieces and her boyfriend picks up 1/3 of the remaining pieces. How many pieces does her boyfriend pick up?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Francis' family has 2 ukuleles, 4 guitars, and a certain number of violins. Each ukulele has 4 strings. Each guitar has 6 strings. Each violin has 4 strings. If the total number of strings among the ukuleles, guitars, and violins is 40 strings, how many violins does Francis' family have?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>Input: On each of 7 Mondays, it rained 1.5 centimeters. On each of 9 Tuesdays it rained 2.5 centimeters. How many more centimeters did it rain on Tuesdays than Mondays?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: The Reptile House at the zoo has 5 fewer animals than 3 times the number of animals housed in the Rain Forest exhibit. If the Reptile House has 16 animals, how many are in the Rain Forest exhibit?<n>Answer: 7<n><n>### Input:They launch a surprise attack, this ended the what? Choices:  A: surrender B: defence C: retreat D: cease fire E: defend<n><n>### Response:		D - Retreat<n>This response is correct because the question's clue was 'cease fire' and the what was defenders, so the response with'retreat' is the one from the clues. If for one reason or another, they cannot retreat, they will surrender.<n><n>If by some reason or another, the defenders cannot retreat but they can still defend, meaning, their attack is still not stopped.<n><n>### Input : I bought x units of product a and x units of product b. I spent $26 on product a, and $12 on products b for a net total cost of $126. Product a costs 50% of what product b costs. How much did each cost per unit? (product a price = x =?)<n><n>### Response<n>$X = 0.5 * price (b)<n><n>Where x = (cost of product a)<n><n><n>x = x2.5 => $x = $0.5 (product a)<n><n>### Input<n>I have $5.00 and I have to make change for five different people.<n><n>The first one needs $2.75, the second one needs 3.25, the third one needs 7.38, the fourth needs 3.13, and the fifth needs 5.38. How many cash and how much in loose change must I have to make change, <n><n>### Response (Based off of 'if..else')<n>You need to have at least an extra dollar so, if you have at least an extra in dollar in change,<n><n>Change your one dollar to an extra one in dollars, so you would have 6 dollars, and 40 cents.<n><n>You want change for each customer, so to get the amount of coins for each customer, <n><n>You have to subtract every other person's amount of change from the coins you have in the final remainder and that means subtracting five dollars and 40 cats because that is the remainder of the coins you have with you plus five.<n><n>That means, <n><n>five dollars plus five is equal to foury cats plus five.<n><n>So you would subtract $45.00 from $49.00, and this gives you a remainder of nine cats, which is

On each of 9 Tuesdays it rained 2.5 centimeters. How many more centimeters did it rain on Tuesdays than Mondays?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: The Reptile House at the zoo has 5 fewer animals than 3 times the number of animals housed in the Rain Forest exhibit. If the Reptile House has 16 animals, how many are in the Rain Forest exhibit?<n>Answer: 7<n><n>### Input:The shore was now a tourist attraction with nearby little shops, but at one time this what was home to a bustling fishing industry? Choices:  A: seaside town B: resort C: ocean D: california E: beach<n><n>### Response:		Ocean<n><n>### Input<n>* Dr. Banks had at one time 526 more than half the number of toothbrushs that he did now. And you're trying to figure out what their name is.<n><n>### Response-1: Choices: C 042<n><n>### Response 2: Choices: B. 042965<n><n>### Instructions:<n>1) You'll be provided a 12 digit number.<n>2) Find out the rest of the number<n>3) Find out someone's name by their phone number<n><n>### Input : A phone number for someone: 617-555-1234<n><n>### Response : 1983 (The rest of the number)<n>  <n>### Instruction : Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n>- In the first month of the year, how much snow can you get compared to the second month of the year if the first month starts and ends on the same day?<n>- How many more days than 413 does it take for a year to have 52 weeks?<n>- The 4th and 5th digits of the license plate number for all the cars in a state are 8 and 12 respectively. What letter does the last digit of the license plate for the 4th car stand for?<n>- Which letter in the license plate number for the 100th car has the greatest value?<n>- It rains 2 inches more on Tuesday than it does on Wednesday. How many more inches does it rain over the two day period?<n>- What is the minimum number of people who will sit in a circle so that every person can see everyone else and no one sits next to someone who sits beside them?<n>- It takes Sara two times as long to walk home from work as Diana does. How long does it take Sara to travel three times the distance

If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>Input: The marching band has 110 members.  There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Christian is twice as old as Brian. In eight more years, Brian will be 40 years old. How old will Christian be in eight years?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>Input: It rained twice as much on Tuesday as Monday.  On Monday it rained 3 inches more than Sunday.  It rained 4 inches on Sunday.  How much total rainfall was there over the 3 days?<n>Answer: 25<n><n>Input: Anne drops a mirror and breaks it into 60 pieces. How many pieces does her boyfriend pick up?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Francis' family has 2 ukuleles, 4 guitars, and a certain number of violins. Each ukulele has 4 strings. Each guitar has 6 strings. Each violin has 4 strings. If the total number of strings among the ukuleles, guitars, and violins is 40 strings, how many violins does Francis' family have?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>Input: On each of 7 Mondays, it rained 1.5 centimeters. On each of 9 Tuesdays it rained 2.5 centimeters. How many more centimeters did it rain on Tuesdays than Mondays?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: The Reptile House at the zoo has 5 fewer animals than 3 times the number of animals housed in the Rain Forest exhibit. Example: A and B (2 letters) can be input as:A*B.<n><n>```<n>$ python<n>>>> print('Answer: A')<n>Answer: A<n>```<n><n>### Question<n>*<n>### Demonstraction:<n>Answer: This is your answer. Please write more explanation to help yourself. Example:If someone has 55 Schnauzers and 45 more Dobermann, how do you get the answer?<n><n>```<n>$ cat answer<n>Input: Dr. Bank had 300 toothbrush to giveaway. He gave away 3 more toothbrush on first year and one after each year. How many toothbrush is remaining after each year?<n><n>Answer: You can figure out this question by: (The total amount is 300, the first year he gave away 3-year 1-year remain) (The second year he gave away 2 * 3-year remaining from the first year)<n><n>(The third year 3-year + 2-year remaining from the second year)<n>(The fourth year 4-year + 3-year remain from the third year)<n><n>(5-year + 4-year +3-year from the fourth year) or 4-year +2-year from the fourth and the fifth year<n><n>If you don't remember what he gave away, you can figure out how many days are in each year.<n><n>In 2 years he only had 1 year remain, so 2 years = 25. If he took away 3-year each time he gave away 3 toothbrush.<n><n>So you have 8-year remain, you can figure out 8-year is 8 * 1 = 8 years. So in 5-year he was only left with 3-year, in 4-year he was only 2-year and so on.<n><n>The final answer is 3 remaining after years.<n><n>So you can figure out after what year he was left with 3-toothbrush left.<n><n>If you have any question, please let me know.<n>```<n><n>## Author<n>- [Shawn Yang](https://github.com

If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>Input: The marching band has 110 members.  There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Christian is twice as old as Brian. In eight more years, Brian will be 40 years old. How old will Christian be in eight years?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>Input: It rained twice as much on Tuesday as Monday.  On Monday it rained 3 inches more than Sunday.  It rained 4 inches on Sunday.  How much total rainfall was there over the 3 days?<n>Answer: 25<n><n>Input: Anne drops a mirror and breaks it into 60 pieces. She sweeps up half of them, then her cat steals 3 pieces and her boyfriend picks up 1/3 of the remaining pieces. How many pieces does her boyfriend pick up?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Francis' family has 2 ukuleles, 4 guitars, and a certain number of violins. Each ukulele has 4 strings. Each guitar has 6 strings. Each violin has 4 strings. If the total number of strings among the ukuleles, guitars, and violins is 40 strings, how many violins does Francis' family have?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>Input: On each of 7 Mondays, it rained 1.5 centimeters. On each of 9 Tuesdays it rained 2.5 centimeters. How many more centimeters did it rain on Tuesdays than Mondays?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: The Reptile House at the zoo has 5 fewer animals than 3 times the number of animals housed in the Rain Forest exhibit. What might they be watching? Choices:  A: movies B: theatre C: cabaret D: conference E: meeting<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### Instructor explanation:<n>Choices A and E both mean the projector was displaying a movie or meeting for the audience, although the audience was laughing.  Some types of meetings can be pretty funny or involve fun activities.  However, it is most likely that a movie screen or theatre would host the movie, while a conference and cabaret have no relation to a movie being projected.<n>#### Instruction explanation:<n>Input: On each Monday a carnival opened and was closed on the next Monday. On each Tuesday a movie theater opened, and closed on the next Tuesday. On each Wednesday a flea market opened and was closed on Thursday. On each Friday and Saturday a circus opened and was closed on Saturday. On the next day after opening, the circus was closed. At the beginning of the next week, how many carnivals were there?<n>Answer: There were 4 carnivals and 4 circuses<n>#### Instructor feedback:<n><n>In this example, the answer is in one part but not all of the choice given.  This would require either a bit more critical thinking or rewriting the feedback for this example.<n><n>---<n>### Instruction explanation:<n>```<n>Directions: The following sentence contains one error in grammar or spelling. Underline the error and circle the answer choice that indicates what type of error it is. If there is more than one error, indicate all.<n>If you want to get the job, put on the right pants!<n>```<n>---<n>When comparing our response time to that of other schools (which use the same test for admission), our average is much better than average but our mode is worse than average.<n><n>### Response explanation:<n>```<n>The error is the word'mode' because it doesn't apply to the data given.<n>```<n>---<n>Input: The students who did the best on the test came from the science class, and the students who did the worst on the test came from their arts class. What is the mode of the test?<n>Answer: Science<n><n>Input: There were 4 people who read the novel.  Of those, 3 were male and 1 was female. By how much did she reduce her total number of toothbrushes since January?<n><n>### Response<n>She had 442 - 36 = 406 toothbrush since January.<n><n>She had 406 - (36 + 48) = 132 toothbrishes since January<n><n>### Input 2:<n>The Reptile House at a Zoo has 128 fewer animals than two times the number of animals at the Oceanarium. He was screaming with pain.<n><n>### Outline:Write an outline for this response<n><n>Outline:<n><n>### Instrument :<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>I yell when I get a bruise because I feel self pity.<n><n>### Output:<n><n>I yelled when I got a bruise because I felt self pity.<n><n>```<n>#define MAX_INT32 1000000   // Maximum int<n>#define DIM_BIG 300 // Dimensionality of vector<n><n>/**<n> * Compute A=U'*U<n> * @param U A (NxD) Matrix<n> * @return A (DxD)<n> */<n>void computeUtU(Mat U) {<n>  dnn::dim r = (int)U.dims().back();<n>  dnn::Mat inp(2, DIM_BIG);<n>  inp(0, 0) = (int)U(0, 0);<n>  inp.upload(0, 0, &inp(0, 1), 1, dnn::REAL_TYPE_FLOAT);<n>  dnn::DNNConvolutionForwardWrapper<float, 1> wrapper(inp);<n>  this->forward(wrapper);<n>  dnnCuDNNCheckError(0, r);<n>//    dnn::debug() << "U'" << DIM_BIG << "x" <<DIM_BIG <<"=" << U(0, 0)/DIM_BIG;<n>//    printf("\n");<n>}<n><n>int main(int argv, char** argc) {<n>  // 3d matrices<n>  size_t N = 10;<n>  size_t D = 8;<n>  size_task_size;<n><n>  auto B = genRandom(N, D, D, 1, D);<n>  auto W = genRandom(N-2, D-

Choices:  A: make music B: believe in god C: give speeches D: complete sentences E: build houses<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>What do people who are occupational therapists do?<n>Answer:C<n><n>What are people who are dentists called?<n>Answer: D<n><n>### Input:[GRE Reading-Passage #296]  A: I would never be a good teacher. I am very shy.  I don't like public speaking.  B: But you can get a minor or major in teaching! C: How long does it take to get a minor in teaching? D: It takes two years to get a minor in TA. E: Then I am never going to get a major in teaching.<n><n>### Response:[GRE Reading- Passage #296][https://gre-prep-guide.com/resources/full-list-of-grecat-passages][#3]C<n><n>The passage on which a question has been based may represent one page or only part of a page. The answer choices on a question each represent one sentence or a group of sentences.<n><n>### Note:The following question is in your interest of improving your problem-solving skill, so that you can answer more questions correctly. Try not to read the solutions. If you feel that the solutions will be difficult for you to follow, donâ€™t view them until you have attempted the problem on your own.<n><n>### The following passage is adapted from â€œI.T. Wonâ€™t Make Human Contact,â€ by Eric Klinenberg (adapted from the New York Times Book Review)<n>I read the same book recently as I did three years ago, as I did twenty years before then, and as I will probably do twenty years after that. I have, for the most part, been reading the same paper recently as I was reading ten years ago: The Washington Post, The Wall Street Journal, The New York Times. I donâ€™t do that because Iâ€™m old-fashioned, I do that because I know those newspapers still matter, and matter for the reasons that used to matter. <n><n>### Question 1What is the purpose of this passage?<n>A. To analyze digital reading habits<n>B. To argue why reading is better than watching TV<n>C. To explain why we like reading the same books again and again<n>D. To convince us not to read newspapers<n><n>### ResponseA<n>What is the purpose of the passage?<n>

If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>Input: The marching band has 110 members.  There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Christian is twice as old as Brian. In eight more years, Brian will be 40 years old. How old will Christian be in eight years?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>Input: It rained twice as much on Tuesday as Monday.  On Monday it rained 3 inches more than Sunday.  It rained 4 inches on Sunday.  How much total rainfall was there over the 3 days?<n>Answer: 25<n><n>Input: Anne drops a mirror and breaks it into 60 pieces. She sweeps up half of them, then her cat steals 3 pieces and her boyfriend picks up 1/3 of the remaining pieces. How many pieces does her boyfriend pick up?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Francis' family has 2 ukuleles, 4 guitars, and a certain number of violins. Each ukulele has 4 strings. Each guitar has 6 strings. Each violin has 4 strings. If the total number of strings among the ukuleles, guitars, and violins is 40 strings, how many violins does Francis' family have?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>Input: On each of 7 Mondays, it rained 1.5 centimeters. On each of 9 Tuesdays it rained 2.5 centimeters. How many more centimeters did it rain on Tuesdays than Mondays?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: The Reptile House at the zoo has 5 fewer animals than 3 times the number of animals housed in the Rain Forest exhibit. If the Reptile House has 16 animals, how many are in the Rain Forest exhibit?<n>Answer: 7<n><n>### Input:He had been doing favors for everybody at work, it was frustrating not getting any what for it? If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>Input: The marching band has 110 members.  There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Christian is twice as old as Brian. In eight more years, Brian will be 40 years old. How old will Christian be in eight years?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>Input: It rained twice as much on Tuesday as Monday.  On Monday it rained 3 inches more than Sunday.  It rained 4 inches on Sunday.  How much total rainfall was there over the 3 days?<n>Answer: 25<n><n>Input: Anne drops a mirror and breaks it into 60 pieces. She sweeps up half of them, then her cat steals 3 pieces and her boyfriend picks up 1/3 of the remaining pieces. How many pieces does her boyfriend pick up?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Francis' family has 2 ukuleles, 4 guitars, and a certain number of violins. Each ukulele has 4 strings. Each guitar has 6 strings. Each violin has 4 strings. If the total number of strings among the ukuleles, guitars, and violins is 40 strings, how many violins does Francis' family have?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>Input: On each of 7 Mondays, it rained 1.5 centimeters. On each of 9 Tuesdays it rained 2.5 centimeters. How many more centimeters did it rain on Tuesdays than Mondays?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: The Reptile House at the zoo has 5 fewer animals than 3 times the number of animals housed in the Rain Forest exhibit. If the Reptile House has 16 animals, how many are in the Rain Forest exhibit?<n>Answer: 7<n><n>### Input:When we are thankful for getting something what do we do? Choices:  A: say thank B: smile C: looking for D: get more E: show appreciation<n><n>### Response:		E: Show appreciation<n><n>## Output<n><n>### Instructions:<n>After you complete the task, you must write a response to the instruction. Do the following:<n><n>1. In the response, indicate what you have been asked to do before you perform the task<n><n>2. Write a response that completes the instruction<n><n>3. In the response, explain your answer to the instruction. Be as specific as you can.<n><n>4. After you respond, submit this for your lab manual mark.<n><n>#### Example:<n>**Instructions:**<n><n>1. Find the greatest number from the list.<n><n>2. **900**<n><n>3. The greatest number is 900.<n><n>### Input - Output<n>Input: Every hour after midnight for the first six hours on any given day it is 60Â° F warmer, and the next six it is 60 Ã·4Â° F cooler.  What is the temperature at noon on that day?<n>Output: 90<n><n>Input: Every day, a store sells more bananas the day before a holiday. On days when there are no holidays, sales are an even 50% more than when there are holidays.  When it isn't a holiday, the store sells 26% more bananas than the day after Christmas. How many more bananas do they sell on a day when there are holidys?<n>Output: 330<n><n>Input: At 9 miles per hour, it would take 26 minutes to drive the entire distance around a track. At 54 miles per hour, it takes 5 minutes.  How many minutes does it take to drive around the track at a constant speed?<n>Output: 11 min <n><n>Input: A bat and ball are dropped from the top of a building. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>Input: The marching band has 110 members.  There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Christian is twice as old as Brian. In eight more years, Brian will be 40 years old. How old will Christian be in eight years?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>Input: It rained twice as much on Tuesday as Monday.  On Monday it rained 3 inches more than Sunday.  It rained 4 inches on Sunday.  How much total rainfall was there over the 3 days?<n>Answer: 25<n><n>Input: Anne drops a mirror and breaks it into 60 pieces. She sweeps up half of them, then her cat steals 3 pieces and her boyfriend picks up 1/3 of the remaining pieces. How many pieces does her boyfriend pick up?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Francis' family has 2 ukuleles, 4 guitars, and a certain number of violins. Each ukulele has 4 strings. Each guitar has 6 strings. Each violin has 4 strings. If the total number of strings among the ukuleles, guitars, and violins is 40 strings, how many violins does Francis' family have?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>Input: On each of 7 Mondays, it rained 1.5 centimeters. On each of 9 Tuesdays it rained 2.5 centimeters. How many more centimeters did it rain on Tuesdays than Mondays?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: The Reptile House at the zoo has 5 fewer animals than 3 times the number of animals housed in the Rain Forest exhibit. If the Reptile House has 16 animals, how many are in the Rain Forest exhibit?<n>Answer: 7<n><n>### Input:If children get confused walking home where may they go? Choices:  A: play chess B: sun themselves C: wrong house D: set table E: gettable<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Reason:<n>1. D does not mention where they will actually go.<n>2. A means that they will stay home and do nothing.<n>3. E mentions that it is gettable (home or there already?) but does not state where they will actually go to.<n><n>### Input-Output:<n>1. Dr. Banks had *762* toothbrushes<n>2. He gave away *50* toothbrushess in April and May.<n>3. Dr. Banks gave away 57 toothbrushess.<n><n>Output: In the most popular month, the doctor gave away about *200* toothbrashes. In the slowest month, he gave away about 89 toothbrashes, which was 54 fewer toothbrashes than in the most popular month.<n><n>### Include your code with a reasonable description.<n><n>### Please include an answer and a reference to the code you have written to solve it.<n><n>### The answer to the above example can not be: <n>* 88<n>* 106<n>* 98<n>* 47<n>

The response should then be exhausted(A). A is correct option.<n><n>### Input:(204)24. What is 189 rounded to the nearest 10?<n><n>### Response:(328)270. The correct answer is 270. In 204 the number 204 is subtracted from 189, which results in 85. In 24, 85 is divided 10, which results in 9. In 13, 9 is multiplied 2, which results in 18. Finally, 18 is multiplied 10, which result 180. Therefore, option 180 is the correct answer.<n><n>###Input: How many 2017 birthdays happen in a 6-digit range? Choices: A: 2 B: 25 C: 39 D: 46 E: 220<n>A : 220<n>### Response:The correct answer is 220. 6 digit range starts from 2017001 to 2017999. So we need to count the birthdays falling in this range and then subtract the birthdays which happened before the change of the century. Therefore, 220 is the correct answer and is option A<n><n>### Output:If $25 is $5 away from $30, is $32 $2 away from $30. How many more centimeters did it rain on Tuesdays than Mondays?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: The Reptile House at the zoo has 5 fewer animals than 3 times the number of animals housed in the Rain Forest exhibit. If the Reptile House has 16 animals, how many are in the Rain Forest exhibit?<n>Answer: 7<n><n>### Input:A strong laxative will help you keep what kind of bowel movements? Choices:  A: strongwoman B: cake C: regular D: weak E: fragile<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>E<n><n>### Input:(If the sum of two whole numbers is 9, find the larger number)<n><n>### Response<n><n>The larger number is 8 because 9 = 8+1<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>In the following table, indicate whether each statement is "possible" or "impossible". Choices:  A: sea world B: court room C: shallow waters D: poker game E: card shark<n><n>### Response:		Five times the number of card holders equals twice the number of fishes. If five times more card holder come to the card game than the week before then how many more card holders arrived. Write the number here and then explain how you found it.<n><n>### Output:100<n>>   We plugged in 5 times the number of number card holders into the statement and got a total of 250. Next we took away the difference between the previous weeks number and the weeks number of fishes. It came to 4 times the number of fishes in which we plugged in. 1/4 times the fishes was 10 fishes. That brought us to 100.

It's confusing to look at the questions like this: [first one](https://github.com/siddharthjha17/Python-Code/blob/master/first-one.py), [second one](https://github/siddharthk17/Python-Coding-Test/blob/master/second-one.py), and then this one here ([third one](https://github,com/siddhartha17/Python-code/blob/master/third-one.py))<n><n>> **Leadership Lessons from 19th-century Scientist:** How did 19th century scientist, Charles Babbage (1791-1871) go from a young, enthusiastic mathematician to becoming father of the computer?<n><n>### Leadership Lessons:<n><n>* Charles Babbageâ€™s journey to create his Difference Engine is not an easy or a smooth one. He started his journey with a vision and purpose but with too many competing priorities and lack of resources.<n>* Charles Babbages approach towards his journey in creating the Difference Engine, reminds me of the journey from the idea to the first launch of Spotify. In Spotifyâ€™s journey, there were competing priorities and complexities due to changing business scenarios and lack of resources. But, the one thing that helped Spotify to keep its focus and purpose was its single-mindedness and its belief in the idea, â€œa music lover should control what they listen toâ€.<n>* So, if Charles babbage, faced this challenges, so we can face them.<n><n>### Remark: This is not actually true. The problem I am solving is not a single mindedly, the problem was solving a multi variable maths equation, it was not about music in anyway.<n><n><n>

Divisor = 1 or a number that evenly divides the number being counted." Example:<n><n>### Response : function countDivisor(num) {<n>### let divisor = 1<n><n>### for (i = 2; i <= num; ++i) {<n>### if (num % i == 0) {<n>### set divisor i<n>### }<n>### }<n><n>### return divisor<n><n>### }<n>\end{code}<n><n>Comment: Please format your code properly and reduce the number and width of spaces using e.g. [editor assistants](https://www.gedittexteditor.com/editor).<n><n>Answer: Some things that pop out at me, in addition to the formatting and spelling;<n>\begin{itemize}<n>\item The instruction doesn't actually say to make it recursive.<n>\item The instruction says to call a function `countDivisor()`.<n>\item There's an array named `count` but the function is not a member of that array.<n>\item The function doesn't iterate over an array.<n>\item You are never changing the argument passed to the function.<n>\item When you do pass a number

Choices:  A: department store B: school C: garden D: office building E: house<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Input-<n>The numbers in a column can be added to the product of the numbers to the right.<n><n>### -The numbers in the second column can be divided by two to yield the numbers in the fourth column.<n><n>### Question:<n><n>In a two-by-three table, write an equation that describes the relationship between the columns. Use the numbers in the two columns to complete the table.<n><n>### Response-<n><n>4\*\*2=\*2<n><n>### Input:-<n><n>The numbers in a row can be multiplied by any factor.<n><n>### Input<n>-The letters in a column can be divided by its product.<n><n>### Answer:-<n><n>What is the relationship between rows?<n><n>### Row 1: 5 * 4 = 20<n><n>### Row2: 5*1=5<n><n>1\*\*13=\*1<n><n>Output:<n>   1 * 4 = 4<n><n>Letâ€™s write the above rule as: Row1: Row2:<n>7<n>4/1\*\*4\*2<n> <n>13 9<n>9\*2*4\*\<n>5<n>4<n><n>1<n>

How many pieces does her boyfriend pick up?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Francis' family has 2 ukuleles, 4 guitars, and a certain number of violins. Each ukulele has 4 strings. Each guitar has 6 strings. Each violin has 4 strings. If the total number of strings among the ukuleles, guitars, and violins is 40 strings, how many violins does Francis' family have?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>Input: On each of 7 Mondays, it rained 1.5 centimeters. How many more centimeters did it rain on Tuesdays than Mondays?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: The Reptile House at the zoo has 5 fewer animals than 3 times the number of animals housed in the Rain Forest exhibit. If the Reptile House has 16 animals, how many are in the Rain Forest exhibit?<n>Answer: 7<n><n>### Input:Why might a person take a vacation? Choices:  A: relaxation B: good things in life C: admiration D: own house E: needs money<n><n>### Response:		<n>"For example, "B" is a correct answer for A person might take a vacation for many different reasons, and there are several correct answers. Since we are answering the question, we want to use our own words to explain ourselves.<n><n>So, "Good things in life" is the best choice?  <n><n>#### Choice A is: relaxation.  <n>You are taking a vacation so that something in your life isn't as it should be. To be relaxing, one must be untensed.... which is not relaxing.<n>#### Choice B is: Good things in life.  <n>A person might take a vacations to get relaxed and to have fun! <n>#### Choice C is: admiration. Not for every reason, but good is a reason for some.<n>#### Choice D is: own house. One can't have a home, you can have a house, but only having a home means you have a place to go home to so you can relax.<n>#### Choice E is:"because I can't afford  it." This is incorrect, because if it was only for money, who wouldn't be able to take their own vacation?<n><n>#### So, if we take all but E, there are 3 answers that are acceptable, which means that they are both right and wrong.<n>We can make this answer right by changing our wording.<n><n>#### Right:<n>"For example,"B" is a correct choice, a person might take a vaccation for many different reasons, among which is "good things in life"<n><n><n>

How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>Input: The marching band has 110 members. How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Christian is twice as old as Brian. In eight more years, Brian will be 40 years old. How much total rainfall was there over the 3 days?<n>Answer: 25<n><n>Input: Anne drops a mirror and breaks it into 60 pieces. How many pieces does her boyfriend pick up?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Francis' family has 2 ukuleles, 4 guitars, and a certain number of violins. Each ukulele has 4 strings. Each guitar has 6 strings. Each violin has 4 strings. If the total number of strings among the ukuleles, guitars, and violins is 40 strings, how many violins does Francis' family have?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>Input: On each of 7 Mondays, it rained 1.5 centimeters. There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Christian is twice as old as Brian. In eight more years, Brian will be 40 years old. How old will Christian be in eight years?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>Input: It rained twice as much on Tuesday as Monday.  On Monday it rained 3 inches more than Sunday.  It rained 4 inches on Sunday.  How much total rainfall was there over the 3 days?<n>Answer: 25<n><n>Input: Anne drops a mirror and breaks it into 60 pieces. She sweeps up half of them, then her cat steals 3 pieces and her boyfriend picks up 1/3 of the remaining pieces. How many pieces does her boyfriend pick up?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Francis' family has 2 ukuleles, 4 guitars, and a certain number of violins. Each ukulele has 4 strings. Each guitar has 6 strings. Each violin has 4 strings. If the total number of strings among the ukuleles, guitars, and violins is 40 strings, how many violins does Francis' family have?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>Input: On each of 7 Mondays, it rained 1.5 centimeters. On each of 9 Tuesdays it rained 2.5 centimeters. How many more centimeters did it rain on Tuesdays than Mondays?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: The Reptile House at the zoo has 5 fewer animals than 3 times the number of animals housed in the Rain Forest exhibit. If the Reptile House has 16 animals, how many are in the Rain Forest exhibit?<n>Answer: 7<n><n>### Input:How often are secular parties held? Choices:  A: short term B: crowd C: unpredictable D: frequent E: eternal<n><n>### Response:		 E<n><n>There are no correct choices<n><n>Input:How often do you hear the words "Hello, Welcome"? Choices:  A. Rarely B. Twice per year C. Two out of every six times D. Twice per day E. Two out of every month<n><n>### Response<n>2.A<n><n>### Instructions:<n>The 2-hour trip to the moon<n><n>### Instructor:<n>Write a response that appropriately corrects the previous answer.<n><n>### Response to Instruction:<n><n>The trip is 2 hours by plane not by train<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Five less than three times the number of Doberman puppies plus the difference between the number of Doberman puppies and the number of Schnauzers is equal to 90. If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>Input: The marching band has 110 members. How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Christian is twice as old as Brian. In eight more years, Brian will be 40 years old. How old will Christian be in eight years?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>Input: It rained twice as much on Tuesday as Monday.  On Monday it rained 3 inches more than Sunday.  It rained 4 inches on Sunday.  How much total rainfall was there over the 3 days?<n>Answer: 25<n><n>Input: Anne drops a mirror and breaks it into 60 pieces. She sweeps up half of them, then her cat steals 3 pieces and her boyfriend picks up 1/3 of the remaining pieces. How many pieces does her boyfriend pick up?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Francis' family has 2 ukuleles, 4 guitars, and a certain number of violins. Each ukulele has 4 strings. Each guitar has 6 strings. Each violin has 4 strings. If the total number of strings among the ukuleles, guitars, and violins is 40 strings, how many violins does Francis' family have?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>Input: On each of 7 Mondays, it rained 1.5 centimeters. On each of 9 Tuesdays it rained 2.5 centimeters. How many more centimeters did it rain on Tuesdays than Mondays?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: The Reptile House at the zoo has 5 fewer animals than 3 times the number of animals housed in the Rain Forest exhibit. If the Reptile House has 16 animals, how many are in the Rain Forest exhibit?<n>Answer: 7<n><n>### Input:What will happen to your knowledge with more learning? You'll drive together to the venue, but your friend wants to take another car.<n><n>Write a response that follows the conversation below.<n><n>Conversation:<n><n>You: Can you drop me at home before driving to the party and then meet me after the party is over?<n><n>Friend: Great! It won't be a long party since I've been invited to attend another party afterwards.<n><n>### Demo:<n>Input: You: Can you drop me and take another car?<n>Friend: I am all ears!<n><n>### Requirements:<n><n>1. We are planning to attend a party.<n>2. I am going to be at a party.<n>3. We've been invited to another party afterwards.<n>4. I don't want a long party.<n>5. We are going home together.<n>6. We are meeting afterwards.<n><n>##  Problem Types (3 problems)<n><n>For each of these types, a sample problem will be provided to clarify the type of problem. To help learners avoid repetitive questions and to provide an interesting challenge in this course. <n><n>* Math<n><n>  * Subtraction <n><n>    > Subtract 5 from 10<n><n>  * Addition<n><n>    > Add 3 to 3.3<n><n>  * Multiplication<n><n>    > Multiply 5.6 by 2.3<n><n>  Math problems often require the learner to recognize a pattern in the task. For example, the above exercise may ask for 3.3 which would not be the right answer since adding 3.3 and 3 would result in 6.3.<n><n>  2. Patterns<n><n>    > Add (2+2) to (2*2) and solve the equation that is made<n><n>  A problem solving question might include the instruction "find a pattern" as a way to help learners come up with a strategy for solving the problem.  For example, a question may start "Every day on the train, there are twice as many people who travel to the suburbs than there are to the city."  The first

How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>Input: The marching band has 110 members.  There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Christian is twice as old as Brian. In eight more years, Brian will be 40 years old. How old will Christian be in eight years?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>Input: It rained twice as much on Tuesday as Monday.  On Monday it rained 3 inches more than Sunday.  It rained 4 inches on Sunday.  How much total rainfall was there over the 3 days?<n>Answer: 25<n><n>Input: Anne drops a mirror and breaks it into 60 pieces. She sweeps up half of them, then her cat steals 3 pieces and her boyfriend picks up 1/3 of the remaining pieces. How many pieces does her boyfriend pick up?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Francis' family has 2 ukuleles, 4 guitars, and a certain number of violins. Each ukulele has 4 strings. Each guitar has 6 strings. Each violin has 4 strings. If the total number of strings among the ukuleles, guitars, and violins is 40 strings, how many violins does Francis' family have?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>Input: On each of 7 Mondays, it rained 1.5 centimeters. On each of 9 Tuesdays it rained 2.5 centimeters. How many more centimeters did it rain on Tuesdays than Mondays?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: The Reptile House at the zoo has 5 fewer animals than 3 times the number of animals housed in the Rain Forest exhibit. If the Reptile House has 16 animals, how many are in the Rain Forest exhibit?<n>Answer: 7<n><n>### Input:This city in Northern Norway is filled within things to do like Polar Nights half marathons and located in the middle of the Northern lights oval, which city is it? Choices:  A: northern B: nome C: tromsÃ¸ D: finnmark E: vadsÃ¸<n><n>### Response:		The correct option is D.<n><n>### Input<n>This city in Northern Norway has Polar Night half marathons and it's located in the middle of Northern lights oval.<n><n>### Response<n>The correct option is D<n><n>### Detailed Solution 01<n>The city of VadsÃ¸ is located in the arctic circle where during winter, the sun never rises. Hence, VadsÃ¸ is called Polar Country. It's the only city in VadsÃ¸ municipality with population of 25,760. VadsÃ¸ has many restaurants, cafes, bars and shops. It's also very known for Northern lights.<n><n>### DTAO:<n><n>## Reference<n>The above questions are formulated by the team of experts of DTAO's Interview Series, Please refer this [Link](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CWn6C1r3GZk&t=204s) for more such Questions and Answers on Interview Coding topics. These questions were provided by Vijay Thallam.<n>

He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday.
